Prompt:
Example 1:
As Johnson worked on math problems with the other female computers, she would ask questions. She didn't want to just do the work — she wanted to know the "hows" and the "whys," and then the "why nots." By asking questions, Johnson began to stand out.
Women were not allowed to attend meetings with the male engineers and scientists. Johnson wanted to go to these meetings to learn more about the projects, so she went. She became known for her training in geometry and began to work with teams made up of men. Eventually, she was recognized as a leader, and the men increasingly relied on her to have the answers they needed.
In 1958, NACA officially became NASA. Shortly thereafter, Johnson became part of the space team. She began calculating the flight path, or trajectory path, for the rocket to put the first American in space in 1961. That American was astronaut Alan Shepard. The engineers knew when and where they wanted Shepard's space capsule to land, but the tricky part was to calculate when and where the rocket would have to launch. Johnson figured it out!

Example 2:
When Naomi saw that Ruth loved her so much, she forgot how tired and hungry she was, and the two journeyed on together until they came to Bethlehem in Judah in the beginning of the barley harvest. There was no famine in Bethlehem. The fields were full of waving grain, and busy servants were reaping it and gathering it up to bind into sheaves. Above all were the fields of the rich man, Boaz, shining with barley and corn.
Naomi and Ruth came to the edge of the fields and watched the busy reapers. They saw that after each sheaf was bound, and each pile of corn was stacked, a little grain fell, unnoticed, to the ground. Ruth said to Naomi: "Let me go to the field and glean the ears of corn after them." And Naomi said to her, "Go, my daughter." And she went, and came and gleaned in the field after the reapers.

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'astronomy' targeting the same readability level (Upper Elementary), limited to 200 words.  

The sun and the stars in the sky were fascinating to look at, but what is more fascinating is the study of the movement of these celestial bodies. This is called astronomy. Astronomers study the stars, the sun, the moon, and the planets to understand how they work and move in space. They use special tools such as telescopes to see these bodies from far away and computers to analyze the data they collect. Astronomers also study the planets in our solar system and how they are affected by the sun's gravity. By studying the movement of the stars and planets, astronomers can learn about the history of the universe and even make predictions about future events in space. By exploring the vastness of the universe, astronomers can help us understand the world we live in and our place in it. They are also working on understanding the mysteries of the universe, like black holes and dark matter. Astronomers are making new discoveries every day that are helping us learn more about the universe.

Prompt:
Example 1:
As Johnson worked on math problems with the other female computers, she would ask questions. She didn't want to just do the work — she wanted to know the "hows" and the "whys," and then the "why nots." By asking questions, Johnson began to stand out.
Women were not allowed to attend meetings with the male engineers and scientists. Johnson wanted to go to these meetings to learn more about the projects, so she went. She became known for her training in geometry and began to work with teams made up of men. Eventually, she was recognized as a leader, and the men increasingly relied on her to have the answers they needed.
In 1958, NACA officially became NASA. Shortly thereafter, Johnson became part of the space team. She began calculating the flight path, or trajectory path, for the rocket to put the first American in space in 1961. That American was astronaut Alan Shepard. The engineers knew when and where they wanted Shepard's space capsule to land, but the tricky part was to calculate when and where the rocket would have to launch. Johnson figured it out!

Example 2:
When Naomi saw that Ruth loved her so much, she forgot how tired and hungry she was, and the two journeyed on together until they came to Bethlehem in Judah in the beginning of the barley harvest. There was no famine in Bethlehem. The fields were full of waving grain, and busy servants were reaping it and gathering it up to bind into sheaves. Above all were the fields of the rich man, Boaz, shining with barley and corn.
Naomi and Ruth came to the edge of the fields and watched the busy reapers. They saw that after each sheaf was bound, and each pile of corn was stacked, a little grain fell, unnoticed, to the ground. Ruth said to Naomi: "Let me go to the field and glean the ears of corn after them." And Naomi said to her, "Go, my daughter." And she went, and came and gleaned in the field after the reapers.

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'astronomy' targeting the same readability level (Upper Elementary), limited to 200 words. 

Astronomy is the study of the universe. It helps us understand the stars, planets, and galaxies. Astronauts like Alan Shepard travel through space to collect data about the universe. Scientists on Earth analyze the data and make new discoveries. They use special equipment to look at the stars and planets, like telescopes and microscopes. With these tools, they can see the universe in new ways. They can even see things that are too far away to see with our eyes. By studying the universe, we can learn about its age, size, and how it was formed. It helps us understand our place in the universe and how we are connected to it. Astronomy is a fascinating field that continues to grow and change as new discoveries are made. It inspires people to explore and learn more about the universe and its many mysteries. It helps us to understand the "hows" and the "whys" of the universe.

Using vocabulary and structure from examples, write a short paragraph about 'astronomy' targeting the same readability level (Upper Elementary), limited to 200 words. 
Astronomy is a branch of science that studies the universe. People who study astronomy want to know about stars, planets, galaxies, and the space between them. Astronomers try to answer questions like, "How big is the universe?" "Are we alone in the universe?" "How did the universe come to be?" To answer these questions, astronomers use powerful telescopes, cameras, and computers to study the stars and planets. They also build satellites that can travel into space to take pictures of the universe. Some astronomers study the stars to learn about their age, size, and color. Others study the planets to learn about their temperature, atmosphere, and possible life. The study of astronomy helps us learn more about the universe and our place in it. It also inspires people to become curious about the world around them and to dream about what lies beyond our planet.
